newsitem.title: GERMANY: German Green sees no point in EMU delay.
newsitem.headline: German Green sees no point in EMU delay.

text.p: A top member of Germany's opposition Greens party said in an interview on Sunday it made no sense to delay European currency union since Bonn's troubled budget situation shows no sign of improving anytime soon.
"If one wants the euro, a delay would not bring any advantages," Christine Scheel, the party's top finance expert, told the Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung weekly.
"The budget situation is not going to improve in the coming years and the fighting over reforms would only last longer."
Germany's government is seeking fresh money to plug a 1997 budget shortfall and reduce its debt level to qualify for currency union, slated to begin on January 1, 1999.

The government and the Bundesbank have been fighting publicly over Finance Minister Theo Waigel's plans to raise money by revaluing the central bank's reserves towards market prices and transferring the proceeds to Bonn.
Scheel told the newspaper that Waigel was to blame for not revaluing the Bundesbank's gold reserves at an earlier time.
"It is Waigel's fault that the revaluation of gold reserves was not done earlier," Scheel said.
"Because of that, the hidden gains of the Bundesbank's reserves cannot be used for the repayment of debt, and it now smells of very creative accounting," she said.
